awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Digital Badges for STEM Education: Designing Networked Learning Environments That Promote High School Students' STEM Identities and Learning Trajectories
awd_abstract_narration:
The digital revolution has transformed how young people discover and pursue their interests; how they communicate with and learn from other people; and how they encounter and learn about the world around them. How can we identify best practices for incorporating new media technologies into learning environments in a way that resonates with youth, including their interests, goals, and the ways they use technology in their everyday lives?  How do we resolve the need to document and recognize informal STEM learning and connect it to formal education contexts?  What strategies can be developed for inspiring and tracking student progress towards the learning goals outlined in the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS)? These questions are the underlying motivation for this CAREER program of research. Digital badges represent a specific kind of networked technology and have been touted as an alternative credentialing system for recognizing and rewarding learning across domains, both inside and outside of formal education contexts. While there is considerable enthusiasm and speculation around the use of digital badges, the extent to which they succeed at empowering learners and connecting their learning across contexts remains largely untested. This project seeks to fill this gap in knowledge.

The approach taken for this program of study is a three phased design-based research effort that will be focused on four objectives: (1) identifying design principles and support structures needed to develop and implement a digital badge system that recognizes informal STEM learning; (2) documenting the opportunities and challenges associated with building a digital badge ecosystem that connects informal learning contexts to formal education and employment opportunities; (3) determining whether and how digital badges support learners' STEM identities; and (4) determining whether and how digital badges help learners to connect their informal STEM learning to formal education and employment opportunities.  In Phase 1, an existing prototype created in prior work at Seattle's Pacific Science Center will be developed into a fully functional digital badge system.  In Phase 2, the PI will also work collaboratively with higher education stakeholders to establish formal mechanisms for recognizing Pacific Science Center badges in higher education contexts. In Phase 3, the badge ecosystem will be expanded and students' use of and engagement with badges will be tracked as they apply to and enter college.

The project involves high school students participating in the Discovery Corps program at the Pacific Science Center, undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Washington, and stakeholders in the K-12 and higher education community in Seattle.  Educational activities integrated with this program of research will support: (1) mentoring University of Washington students throughout the project to develop their skills as practice-oriented researchers; (2) incorporating the research processes and findings from the project into university courses aimed at developing students' understanding of the opportunities and challenges associated with using new media technologies to support learning; and (3) using the research findings to develop educational outreach initiatives to support other informal STEM learning institutions in their use of digital badges.

por.por_cntn:
The digital revolution has transformed how young people discover and pursue their interests; how they communicate with and learn from other people; and how they encounter and learn about the world around them. How can we identify best practices for incorporating networked technologies into learning environments in a way that resonates with youth, including their interests, goals, and the ways they use technology in their everyday lives?  How do we resolve the need to document and recognize informal STEM learning and connect it to formal education contexts?  These questions were the underlying motivation for this CAREER program of research. Digital badges represent a specific kind of networked technology and have been touted as an alternative credentialing system for recognizing and rewarding learning across domains, both inside and outside of formal education contexts. While there is considerable enthusiasm and speculation around the use of digital badges, the extent to which they succeed at empowering learners and connecting their learning across contexts had remained largely untested before this project.

The major goals of the Digital Badges for STEM Education Project were to: (1) identify design principles and support structures needed to develop and implement a digital badge system that recognizes informal STEM learning; (2) document the opportunities and challenges associated with building a digital badge ecosystem that connects informal learning contexts to formal education and employment opportunities; (3) determine whether and how digital badges support learners’ STEM identities; and (4) determine whether and how digital badges help learners to connect their informal STEM learning to formal education and employment opportunities.

The project took place between May 1, 2015 – May 31, 2021 and involved high school students participating in the Discovery Corps program at Seattle Pacific Science Center, undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Washington, and stakeholders in the K-12 and higher education community in Seattle. The project team developed, implemented, and evaluated a digital badge system that recognizes high school students’ learning achievements at an afterschool science center. The system was co-designed iteratively with students and program staff. 

Following the design and implementation of the badge system, the research team continued to work with students and staff in the Discovery Corps Program to iterate on the initial design based on field-based observations and direct feedback (surveys, interviews, and participatory design sessions with students). We also conducted interviews with external stakeholders such as college admissions officer and prospective employers to elicit their views on the potentials and challenges associated with digital badges.

Our research revealed enthusiasm among students, program supervisors, and external stakeholders regarding the potential for digital badges to make student learning more visible and help connect students’ out-of-school learning accomplishments to other learning contexts and future education and employment opportunities. At the same time, our research identified challenges associated with incorporating a new sociotechnical system into an existing learning environment that has pre-established norms and practices. Through our long-term work with the afterschool program, we identified and implemented processes for addressing this challenge of adoption such that the badge system became more fully integrated into the structure of the daily workflow of the program. Another challenge we identified pertained to the reception of badges shared externally to stakeholders such as college admissions officers and employers. In our interviews with these stakeholders, they expressed the view that the badges had the potential to represent credible evidence of skills and accomplishments but only once they were endorsed by reputable institutions and more broadly accepted in educational and professional spheres.

The findings from the Digital Badges for STEM Education Project contributed to education research by documenting the best practices associated with and obstacles to using sociotechnical systems like digital badges to accomplish the following goals: (1) connect students’ STEM learning contexts across formal and informal settings; (2) develop students’ STEM identities; and (3) introduce students to future STEM-related learning and career opportunities. Each of these goals represents an ongoing challenge in the field of education.

Our work also explored new directions and developments in participatory design (PD), using our design sessions with students as a basis to contribute deeper understanding of PD to the fields of Human-Computer Interaction and Child-Computer Interaction. In our published work, we have examined the opportunities and challenges of incorporating teenagers into the design process with other adult stakeholders, and we have provided guidance for others looking to work on similar projects. In addition, we have identified and examined tensions in how badge systems and related connected learning constructs operate in teens' sociotechnical ecosystems.

The insights from this work will inform future work addressing the design and long-term implementation of digital badges in educational contexts. This work also has broader applicability with respect to designing and implementing other education-focused sociotechnical systems that aim to support student learning.
